item.title: The Trade War Couldn’t Change China’s Economy
item.description: American hopes for political reform in China faded years ago, and now hopes for economic liberalization are fading too.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: White House to Announce Resumption of Auto Chip Shipments From China
item.description: Nexperia hasn’t shipped chips for weeks, putting car production around the world at risk.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Felton

item.title: Trump Says He’s Not Planning Venezuela Strike
item.description: The president had said recently the U.S. was considering strikes against targets in the country.
item.dc:creator: Anvee Bhutani

item.title: Israel’s Top Military Lawyer Steps Down Amid Leak Controversy
item.description: The official resigned after an investigation was launched into her alleged role in authorizing the release of footage that appeared to show soldiers assaulting a Palestinian detainee.
item.dc:creator: Feliz Solomon

item.title: Argentina Has the World’s Weirdest Tax. Can Milei Scrap it?
item.description: Argentina’s export tax hurts its critical agricultural industry. President Javier Milei has yet to follow through on a promise to end it.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Key Moments in the Downfall of Prince Andrew
item.description: The British royal’s unprecedented disgrace follows years of scandal and sexual-abuse allegations.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Dangoor

item.title: Why Buckingham Palace Decided to Get Rid of Andrew
item.description: In demoting the errant prince, King Charles hopes to get the monarchy scandal-free for his son William.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: Inside the Low-Tech Heist That Penetrated the Louvre
item.description: The men who stole France’s crown jewels cut corners—mistakes that led authorities to track down three suspected thieves.
item.dc:creator: Noemie Bisserbe

item.title: BOE to Embrace Uncertainty, and Bernanke’s Guidance, With Communications Revamp
item.description: The central bank place will more emphasis on developments that could upend its expectations and less on forecasts that convey too much certainty about the future.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sudan Militia, Armed With Drones, Hunts Down Black Population of Darfur
item.description: The country’s civil war has triggered a wave of brutal reprisals targeting the region’s Black population.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: How Chevron Got Caught in the Clash Between the U.S. and Venezuela
item.description: Chief Executive Mike Wirth has orchestrated a yearslong campaign to keep the Latin American country open for oil production.
item.dc:creator: Kejal Vyas

item.title: China Factory Activity Gauge Signals Deepening Manufacturing Gloom
item.description: Economic momentum continued to weaken for the world’s second-largest economy, with a manufacturing gauge signaling mounting headwinds.

item.title: Hezbollah Is Rearming, Putting Cease-Fire at Risk
item.description: The Lebanese militant group is rebuilding its battered ranks and armaments, defying the terms of the cease-fire and raising the possibility of renewed conflict with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: The Long Road to a U.S.-China Trade Pact
item.description: The Trump administration had for months been reluctant to reduce America’s fentanyl-based tariffs on Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Trump Pivots Second Term Toward Foreign Policy
item.description: By engaging in dealmaking and peace talks, the president is in search of a legacy-defining victory.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: U.S. Eyes Striking Venezuelan Military Targets Used for Drug Trafficking
item.description: If President Trump decides to move forward with airstrikes, the targets would send a clear message to Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro that it is time to step down, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Vera Bergengruen

item.title: Prince Andrew Stripped of Royal Title by King Charles
item.description: Andrew’s friendship with Jeffrey Epstein and new revelations about longstanding abuse allegations forced the king’s hand.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Opinion | Hamas, Free Speech and Arizona University
item.description: Emails from 2023-24 reveal anti-Israel and pro-Hamas bias among the faculty and student groups.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Lessons From Trump’s China Trade War
item.description: Beijing fought back, and it’s hard to see what tariffs achieved for the U.S.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | New Start and Trump’s Nuclear Test
item.description: The President is right that the U.S. needs to modernize its deterrent to match China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Rebeccah L. Heinrichs

item.title: Dutch Hard-Right Leader Geert Wilders Set to Exit Power
item.description: The Freedom Party’s drop in support holds lessons for Europe’s resurgent far-right.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Trade Deal With China’s Xi
item.description: Tariffs, soybean purchases and a crackdown on fentanyl were among the issues discussed by the two leaders.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: The Canada-U.S. Trade War Is Pushing Carney Closer to Xi
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is expected to meet with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on Friday at the APEC leaders summit in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Yoko Kubota

item.title: Opinion | Zelensky Is Winning Trump Voters Over
item.description: Polling shows Ukraine re-emerging as a Republican priority.
item.dc:creator: Colby Barrett

item.title: Opinion | Sorry Republicans, There’s No Silver Lining to a Mamdani Win
item.description: If the GOP doesn’t govern well, the voters may prove surprisingly open to ‘unelectable’ Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Joseph C. Sternberg

item.title: U.S.-China Truce Brings Little Peace for Businesses Caught in Superpower Standoff
item.description: Washington and Beijing haven’t addressed their underlying conflicts, and commerce is going to be rocky for years to come.
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Huang

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Latest Tariffs
item.description: A roundup of where things stand with tariffs on key U.S. trade partners and sectors.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham

item.title: Al Qaeda Is on the Brink of Taking Over a Country
item.description: If the jihadists succeed in taking Mali, it would become the first country run by the group. The U.S. has warned its citizens to leave the West African nation immediately.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: As China Raises Pressure, U.S. to Support Seoul in Building Nuclear-Powered Sub
item.description: South Korea told President Trump a stealthy submarine will reduce the burden on American forces as threats from Beijing and Pyongyang rise.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: Hurricane Melissa Barrels Through Bahamas After Lashing Cuba
item.description: The hurricane brought heavy rain, widespread flooding and winds close to 100 miles an hour to the central and southeast Bahamas.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Pisani

item.title: Police Make Five New Arrests in Louvre Heist
item.description: The overnight raids across Paris included the arrest of a man who prosecutors suspect of directly taking part in the jewel theft.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: See the Secret Networks Smuggling Drugs to the U.S. From Latin America
item.description: Maps and charts show the challenges to President Trump’s strategy of blowing up alleged drug boats.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Trump Meets With Xi, Declares Immediate Cut to Tariffs
item.description: The leaders’ first face-to-face summit in six years offered relief to both sides, while the high-stakes rivalry between the U.S. and China carries on.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: Israel Accuses Hamas of Playing a Macabre Game With Hostage Bodies
item.description: Israeli officials say the militant group is deliberately delaying the return of hostages’ bodies to gain time to consolidate power and reassert its control over Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: Trump, South Korea Reach Terms on Trade Deal
item.description: The surprise breakthrough follows months of contentious talks over $350 billion in investments Seoul has pledged to America.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: U.S. Reduces Troop Numbers in Romania, Signaling Shifting Priorities
item.description: The Pentagon will no longer rotate Army combat brigades through Romania as part of a strategy that focuses on Asia and Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: Opinion | How China Enables Russia’s Military
item.description: New evidence shows the supply-chain trail aiding Moscow’s drone makers.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Two Suspects in Louvre Heist Are Caught Without Jewels
item.description: The Paris prosecutor said two men suspected of breaking into the museum lived on the outskirts of the French capital.
item.dc:creator: Noemie Bisserbe

item.title: Israel Says Cease-Fire Is Back On After Gaza Strikes
item.description: Repeated rounds of violence suggest fighting could continue at a lower intensity.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: On Trump’s Asia Trip, Many Opportunities Were Golden
item.description: The president has made gold an essential part of his personal brand for decades. Foreign leaders are using his penchant for it to win his favor.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: Trump Tells Asia Allies: It’s Your Turn to Boost Military Spending
item.description: During a six-day tour of a region facing the threat of Chinese aggression, Trump reiterates a message that was largely heeded by European nations.
item.dc:creator: Lara Seligman

item.title: Netanyahu Orders ‘Forceful’ Strikes on Gaza
item.description: Israel alleged Hamas launched an attack against troops in Israeli-controlled territory in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Lara Seligman

item.title: Trump Hails Golden Era in Japan Relations
item.description: The president heaped praise on Japan’s first female prime minister as the two leaders pledged to renew their countries’ alliance aboard a U.S. aircraft carrier.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Washington’s Oil Dilemma Returns: How to Hurt Moscow Without Raising Gas Prices
item.description: Enforcing tough measures against one of the world’s top oil producers risks triggering a supply shock.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: Welcome to Johannesburg. This Is What It Looks Like When a City Gives Up.
item.description: Tourists are dumbfounded by the many signs of apathy in the South African city.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: After Demolishing U.S.-China Relationship, Trump Is Rebuilding It His Way
item.description: A summit between the president and Chinese leader Xi Jinping marks renewed engagement in a long-term superpower rivalry.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: A Trip to Gaza’s New ‘Yellow Line’ Shows Israel Is Digging In
item.description: The temporary dividing line between two foes is becoming more permanent, with earthworks and plans for civilian infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: How U.A.E. Arms Bolstered a Sudanese Militia Accused of Genocide
item.description: Reports by U.S. intelligence agencies show an increase in the flow of materiel from the U.A.E. to the rebel Rapid Support Forces since the spring, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Putin Uses Old Missile Technology to Send a New Message to the West
item.description: President Vladimir Putin hailed the first long-distance test of a nuclear-powered cruise missile that he said has no equal in the West.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Michaels

item.title: China Pushes to Silence Victims of African Mining Disaster
item.description: Toxic waste from a Chinese mine in Zambia washed through homes and fields. Compensation offers are tied to nondisclosure.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Sudanese Rebels, Accused of Genocide, Seize Key City
item.description: The capture of the El Fasher gives the rebel Rapid Support Forces the last government stronghold in Darfur, where they have twice been accused of committing genocide.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Milei Wins Mandate for Free-Market Revolution in Argentina’s Election
item.description: President Javier Milei scored a decisive political win Sunday, tightening his grip on Argentina’s Congress.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Japan Woos Trump With a Royal Welcome
item.description: A meeting with the country’s emperor, though short on pomp, aimed to warm up the president at the start of his visit.
item.dc:creator: Junko Fukutome

item.title: Headroom Yet to Be Decided as U.K. Prepares for Key Budget
item.description: The government is expected to raise taxes, but the size of those increases will partly depend on how large a margin for error it wants as it aims to meet its fiscal rules.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: How Russia’s Sanctioned Arctic Gas Found a Chinese Loophole
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have tried to cripple Russia’s energy industry, but Moscow has found loopholes time and again.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Feng

item.title: Fear Grips a Caribbean Nation in the Shadow of U.S. Boat Strikes
item.description: In Trinidad and Tobago, fishermen are staying home and a family mourns following airstrikes on alleged drug boats.
item.dc:creator: Kejal Vyas

item.title: State Department Intelligence Agency Dissented Over Putin’s Appetite for Peace
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency had a more positive assessment of the Russian leader’s willingness to talk.
item.dc:creator: Brett Forrest

item.title: A Hiking Death Roils a Fashion Empire and the Heirs to a Fortune
item.description: Almost a year after billionaire Isak Andic fell off a cliff in Spain, his demise remains under investigation and hangs over the Mango fast-fashion company.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Strasburg

item.title: As Putin Digs In, a Long—and Different—War With Ukraine Looms
item.description: Long-range strikes on infrastructure are becoming increasingly critical as front-line advances stall.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Will India and China Be Able to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Russian Oil?
item.description: New Delhi and Beijing have so far resisted U.S. calls to stop buying Russian crude, but far-reaching sanctions will be hard to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Jiahui Huang

item.title: U.K. Inflation Unexpectedly Holds Steady
item.description: The country’s annual rate of inflation in September was at the same pace seen in August, but was still well above the Bank of England’s target.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Trump Signals Support for Selling Submarines to Australia
item.description: The president’s comments calmed fears that he would pull out of the Biden-era deal and came as he struck an agreement with the U.S. ally on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: How a Right-Wing Hindu Group Went From Fringe to Mainstream in India
item.description: India’s Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh group is stepping out of the shadows and flexing its power.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Trump Organization Expands in India, Where Many of Its Partners Face Accusations
item.description: Indian real-estate firms have been accused of fraud, money laundering and more on other projects. The Trumps have stepped up overseas deals in the president’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grant

item.title: India Delicately Counters Trump Claim It Will Drop Russian Oil
item.description: New Delhi didn’t outright contradict the president, saying it was committed to protecting consumers by diversifying its energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: The Path to the American Dream Is Narrowing for Indian Tech Workers
item.description: About 70% of H-1B visas go to Indians. Looming changes to the program are upending plans, but may help India retain talent.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Selinger

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.
item.dc:creator: Sal Vaglica

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.
item.dc:creator: Sarah E. Needleman

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
